author: RaulJuncoV
full_text:
A common mistake I see:

People treat message queues and streams as if they’re interchangeable.

They’re not.

Here’s the difference 👇

Message Queue (MQ)

- Designed for delivery guarantees (at-least-once, exactly-once).
- Great for sporadic workloads and asynchronous tasks.
- https://t.co/tKedfx4XPC
note_tweet_text:
A common mistake I see:

People treat message queues and streams as if they’re interchangeable.

They’re not.

Here’s the difference 👇

Message Queue (MQ)

- Designed for delivery guarantees (at-least-once, exactly-once).
- Great for sporadic workloads and asynchronous tasks.
- Messages are consumed and removed. Once acknowledged, they’re gone.
- Think: order processing, background jobs, retry logic.

Stream

- Designed for real-time, high-throughput, continuous data.
- Data is append-only and replayable.
- Multiple consumers can read the same stream independently.
- Think: real-time analytics dashboards, fraud detection, monitoring pipelines.

Why Streams fit Aaron’s case (real-time analytics for e-commerce):

- Freshness matters → Streams process events as they arrive, with low latency.
- Replayability matters → If a consumer goes down, it can re-read from the offset.
- Scale matters → Streams partition data for massive parallel consumption.

A message queue here would introduce unnecessary latency and discard historical events that analytics needs to stay accurate.

Rule of thumb:
- If you care about delivery → Message Queue.
- If you care about freshness & scale → Stream.

That’s why the right answer here is: Streams for real-time analytics.
cognitive_value: CSS transforms and animations enable engaging UI interactions.

note_tweet_text:
you're sleeping on scraping while others are building $15k/month businesses from public data

fact: web scrapers + simple ui = $10k/month saas products

most people think scraping is "too technical" or "unethical"

wrong

it's literally just reading public data that's already visible to everyone

here's the stupidly simple stack that's printing money:

→ apify for scraping (no code needed, pre-built scrapers)
→ supabase to store data (auto-updates on schedule)
→ lovable for simple search ui
→ charge for organized, searchable access

real examples making serious money:

"job listings for remote developers" → $29/month
scrapes 20 job sites daily

"product price tracker" → $19/month
tracks amazon, ebay, competitor prices

"grant database for nonprofits" → $99/month
scrapes government sites automatically

"real estate listings" → $49/month
aggregates public listings with advanced filters

the process is dead simple:

1, find data people want but it's scattered
2, use apify's pre-built scrapers (click to scrape indeed, amazon, etc,)
3, schedule daily updates in supabase
4, build basic search interface
5, users pay for convenience, not data itself

what people get wrong about legality:

scraping public data is 100% legal (linkedin vs hiq confirmed this)

just follow basic rules:

✓ public data only (no login walls)
✓ respect robots,txt
✓ use rate limits
✓ add value through organization

apify handles all technical complexity + legal compliance

here's the pricing psychology:

users don't pay for data access
they pay for time savings

"instead of checking 20 sites daily, check our dashboard" = worth $29/month to busy professionals

proof this works at scale:

→ hunter,io (email scraper) - millions in revenue
→ built with (technology scraper) - massive business
→ importyeti (shipping data) - acquired for millions

every industry has scattered data someone would pay to organize

first movers win these markets

while you're overthinking, competitors are already building

SORA 2 + Claude + Perplexity is absolutely WILD

This combo is absolutely insane for generating videos that actually convert.

No agencies. No production crews. No creative directors charging $500/hour.

→ Best performers get refined and regenerated automatically

Perplexity = market intelligence most creative teams miss
Claude = prompts that understand psychology and platform algorithms
Sora 2 = production quality that looks like you spent $5K per video

author: oprydai
full_text:
phases of learning robotics:

phase 1 → curiosity
you see a robot online, think “this is magic.”

phase 2 → basics
arduino, sensors, motors. everything feels clunky but exciting.

phase 3 → reality check
math hits you. kinematics, dynamics, control theory. you wonder if you’re
note_tweet_text:
phases of learning robotics:

phase 1 → curiosity
you see a robot online, think “this is magic.”

phase 2 → basics
arduino, sensors, motors. everything feels clunky but exciting.

phase 3 → reality check
math hits you. kinematics, dynamics, control theory. you wonder if you’re cut out for this.

phase 4 → systems thinking
you stop seeing “parts” and start seeing the robot as a whole: hardware + software + electronics + math.

phase 5 → building
your prototypes break. often. but each rebuild sharpens your instincts.

phase 6 → mastery
you move past tutorials. you start creating your own architectures, your own designs, your own robots.

phase 7 → contribution
you’re no longer just learning. you’re pushing the field forward.

which phase are you in?

I don't consider myself an AI doomer or pessimist.

- How AI capex break down
- Why the AI build-out is different from past infrastructure projects, like the railroad and dot-com build-outs

- Why the entire financial system is balancing on big chip-makers like Nvidia

the 12 month sora 2 roadmap:

1/ pick a niche and flood it. post 15x daily. copy human formats that already work (shorts, memes, explainers). test until one hits.

2/ once you find the format, lock it. build a character or brand people attach to. identity becomes your moat.

3/
note_tweet_text:
the 12 month sora 2 roadmap:

1/ pick a niche and flood it. post 15x daily. copy human formats that already work (shorts, memes, explainers). test until one hits.

2/ once you find the format, lock it. build a character or brand people attach to. identity becomes your moat.

3/ package & sell workflows/styles. 6–7 figs profit. gets you sharper at prompts. skip if you’ve raised VC.

4/ ride the arbitrage. early youtube → tiktok → now sora. algorithm over-rewards new formats for ~12 months. milk it.

5/ layer on community. discord. whatsapp groups. newsletter. capture the people who care about the brand

6/ build apps for your audience. use bolt/lovable/expo/rork/vibecode. find startup ideas @ideabrowser.

7/ incubate related apps into a portfolio. stack cross-promo. hit $100k MRR and decide: sell bundle or keep compounding.

8/ merch, events, commerce. distribution unlocks everything else.

9/ by month 12,  you have either:

nothing worked, because you couldnt find formats that worked on sora (keep going) or 

a cash-flowing machine, or

an unfair distribution edge that makes your next move cheaper, faster, easier.

WE ALL WANT THAT DISTRIBUTION EDGE. that's why paying attention to sora 2 matters so muuuuch

10/ glhf. i want to see you crush it.

have a creative day, friends.
cognitive_value: Minimum Lovable Product balances speed with essential features.

note_tweet_text:
i've been thinking about sora 2 (what it means for you, where the $$ can be made):

1/ someone will buy a synthetic Sora 2 style account for $10M and it will be a good deal but will look crazy

2/ whoever builds the “no-AI instagram” that takes off makes $100M-$1B. because social feeds will drown in Sora spam. networks that ban AI content, add verification layers will thrive.

3/ people start selling their own likeness. “rent my face for $99/month.” agencies become gatekeepers of likeness rights. the scarjo fight is the first domino.

4/ someone will build a daily Sora channel, flip it into a $50M+ AI startup within 18 months completely bootstrapped.

5/ in 3 months, feeds will be unrecognizable. 1-person “ai-first creators” dropping 200 vids/day. the ones who figure out hooks + branding → next gen MrBeasts.

6/ creation goes to zero cost, so ppl who own the pipes (big accounts, media pages, curation brands) will tax the flood. 2010s meme pages all over again, but cinema-quality. 

7/ someone will mint a Sora-native character that builds an empire (music, merch, movies). think hello kitty x mrbeast. content making influencers are the new influencers

8/ people start selling their own likeness. “rent my face for $99/month.” agencies become gatekeepers of likeness rights. the scarjo fight is the first domino.

9/ 1,000 ad variations overnight is the new normal → cpm wars. who wins? the ppl who build the distribution machines that can test + filter that flood.

10/ tooling gold rush - watermarking, copyright detection, brand overlays. when the world drowns in video, verification tools become choke points.

11/ movies won’t die, but they’ll be swallowed by endless serialized micro-shows. one breakout sora-native series hits, netflix panics.

12/ memes/genres that used to last years now die in weeks. whoever masters the rhythm of fast-burn cycles builds audience the fastest.

13/ platforms double dip - they’ll host the flood and sell you boosts to cut through it. organic reach might fall (i hope not, but manage your risk accordingly)

14/ vertical content studios rise - apps for niches: Sora-for-fitness, Sora-for-real estate listings, Sora-for-crypto memes. packaged prompts + workflows + export buttons.

15/ hollywood talent agencies will pivot into “likeness funds.” they’ll securitize the rights to actors’ faces and voices like IP portfolios. sidenote: hollywood prob not feeling so great about this

16/ Synthetic “how-to” teachers will dominate niches. Think Khan Academy, but cloned 1,000x and personalized to every learner.

17/ distribution curators will be the new venture capitalists. Whoever can guarantee views will become gatekeepers.

18/ copyright courts will get nuked. The first $1B+ lawsuit over Sora likeness rights will set precedent for a new industry.

19/ a religion will literally form around a Sora-generated prophet. sounds insane. it will happen. 

20/ synthetic nostalgia startups will raise hundreds of millions. recreate your 7th birthday, your grandma’s kitchen, your lost dog. It’ll be addictive.

21/ a real estate startup will generate cinematic walk-throughs of homes before they’re built, then sell them instantly. $1B company.

22/ in 5-10 years, people won’t ask “what’s your favorite show?” they’ll ask “what’s your favorite generator?”

in the next tweet I’ll outline the steps I’d personally take to make $$/earn distribution from sora 2 in a few steps

sora 2 is a big deal

i can't sleep thinking about it, idk about you

author: JafarNajafov
full_text:
Wild: Anthropic just proved that prompt engineering is dead. Context engineering is the new game, and it changes everything about building AI agents 🤖

For years, we obsessed over the perfect prompt.

The right words. The perfect phrasing. The magic sentence that makes GPT-4 https://t.co/HnCRBbkakw
note_tweet_text:
Wild: Anthropic just proved that prompt engineering is dead. Context engineering is the new game, and it changes everything about building AI agents 🤖

For years, we obsessed over the perfect prompt.

The right words. The perfect phrasing. The magic sentence that makes GPT-4 finally understand what you want.

But Anthropic just dropped a reality check:

Prompts are the easy part. Context is the bottleneck.

Here's what they found:

→ LLMs have an "attention budget" like human working memory, but for tokens
→ More context = worse performance (they call it "context rot")
→ The transformer architecture creates n² relationships between tokens
→ Every token you add depletes focus exponentially

Translation? Stuffing your AI with information is like trying to focus while 50 people scream at you.

So what's the new playbook?

↳ Just-in-time retrieval
- Instead of loading everything upfront, agents pull data dynamically using tools
- Claude Code does this brilliantly: it uses grep, head, tail to analyze databases without ever loading full files into context

↳ Compaction
- Summarize the conversation when you hit limits
- Keep architectural decisions, discard redundant tool outputs
- Maintain continuity without context bloat

↳ Structured note-taking
- Agents write persistent notes outside the context window
- Pull them back only when needed
- Think: AI maintaining its own https://t.co/xZDZxFLBJK file

↳ Sub-agent architectures
- Specialized agents handle focused tasks
- Return compressed summaries (2k tokens) instead of raw exploration (50k+ tokens)
- Separation of concerns at the AI level

The shift is profound:

Before: "How do I write the perfect prompt?"
Now: "What's the minimal high-signal context that drives my desired outcome?"

This isn't just academic.

Goldman Sachs is using AI to draft S1s.
Perplexity is automating financial analysis.
Claude Code is refactoring entire codebases.

None of this works if you drown the AI in context.

The best AI engineers aren't prompt wizards anymore.

They're context architects.
cognitive_value: Vibe coding course provides practical AI-assisted development skills.

author: NickK2305
full_text:
things no fullstack roadmap will ever teach you🔥

(6/100) - State Management  

state bugs kill more frontend projects than css ever will.
  
1. server vs client state 
- client state = ui stuff (modal open, input value).  
- server state = data from api (user, posts, settings).
note_tweet_text:
things no fullstack roadmap will ever teach you🔥

(6/100) - State Management  

state bugs kill more frontend projects than css ever will.
  
1. server vs client state 
- client state = ui stuff (modal open, input value).  
- server state = data from api (user, posts, settings).
  
mistake: treating both the same → endless bugs.  

2. cache invalidation in the frontend 
fetch once, never refetch = stale ui.  
blind refetch = network spam.  

tools like react-query / swr → handle stale-while-revalidate, background refresh, retries.  

3. optimistic updates  
user clicks “like” → ui updates instantly.  
rollback if server rejects.  

this makes apps *feel fast*. without it, your product feels laggy.  

4. global vs local 
context/zustand/redux for global state only.  

don’t dump every input field into redux. local ui state should stay local.  

5. hydration & rsc
with next.js/react server components, server state can hydrate into the client.  

mix carefully → don’t over-fetch, don’t double-fetch.  

👉🏻 mini-project:
- next.js app with react-query + zustand  
- fetch posts → swr revalidate every 30s  
- implement “like” button with optimistic ui + rollback  
- modal + form state managed locally (not redux)

“SHOW ME”

Not “replace.”
Not “change.”
Not “modify.”

Just:
“show me an aerial shot”
“show me a side shot of that person”
“show me the girl with blue hair”

Everything else? Straight into the void.

author: JustAnotherPM
full_text:
It's been over a decade since I started working as a product manager. 

I've worked with, reported to, and mentored some of the most amazing PMs in the world.  

And you know what I've noticed? 

Most of them think of success metrics as a complicated rocket-sciency subject. When https://t.co/5s5zOwSoym
note_tweet_text:
It's been over a decade since I started working as a product manager. 

I've worked with, reported to, and mentored some of the most amazing PMs in the world.  

And you know what I've noticed? 

Most of them think of success metrics as a complicated rocket-sciency subject. When it is actually a simple thought exercise instead.

So here is everything I know today.

Things to remember:
- Limit total metrics to 5-8
- Don't over complicate them
- Metric is an answer to a question
- The goal is to ask the right questions
- Don't use metrics that can be cheated
- There is never a "perfect" list of metrics
- Think of ALL users when creating metrics

Keep your approach simple
1. Think in broad buckets
2. Determine primary aspect to measure
3. Think of questions you want to answer
4. Find a metric that answers the question
5. Avoid common mistakes

For ex: in this chart -- I would focus on answering each question with a metric that is simple, easy-to-understand for others, and actionable.
--

What would you you improve in this approach?

What approach do you use?
cognitive_value: Prompt engineering courses teach effective AI communication techniques.

author: nurijanian
full_text:
Junior PM: The roadmap got pushed again. Leadership changed priorities without warning.

Senior PM: What are you doing about it?

Junior PM: Nothing I can do. They made the decision.

Senior PM: They made a decision. You still have choices.

Junior PM: Like what? I don't control
note_tweet_text:
Junior PM: The roadmap got pushed again. Leadership changed priorities without warning.

Senior PM: What are you doing about it?

Junior PM: Nothing I can do. They made the decision.

Senior PM: They made a decision. You still have choices.

Junior PM: Like what? I don't control the roadmap priorities.

Senior PM: You control how you respond.

Junior PM: I already told my team. We're deprioritized.

Senior PM: That's informing. Not responding.

Junior PM: What else is there?

Senior PM: You could understand why priorities shifted.

Junior PM: I know why. The CEO wants to chase a new market.

Senior PM: Do you understand the business case?

Junior PM: Not really my level...

Senior PM: There it is.

Junior PM: There's what?

Senior PM: Your cage. "Not my level."

Junior PM: But I'm just a PM. I don't make strategy.

Senior PM: You don't make it. Can you influence it?

Junior PM: How would I influence the CEO?

Senior PM: Not the CEO. The decision.

Junior PM: ...I could build a stronger case for our feature?

Senior PM: Keep going.

Junior PM: Show how our feature actually helps enter that new market?

Senior PM: Now you're thinking with agency.

Junior PM: But what if they still say no?

Senior PM: Then you find another angle.

Junior PM: That sounds exhausting.

Senior PM: Know what's more exhausting?

Junior PM: What?

Senior PM: Being brilliant but powerless.

Junior PM: So High Agency means never accepting "no"?

Senior PM: High Agency means never accepting "nothing I can do."

Junior PM: There's always something?

Senior PM: Always. Even if it's just changing your approach.

Junior PM: My last manager would say "pick your battles."

Senior PM: Your last manager was teaching you to be mediocre.

Junior PM: Harsh.

Senior PM: True. Watch the best PMs. They don't pick battles. They pick outcomes.

Junior PM: And they just... make them happen?

Senior PM: They find ways. Legal ways. Ethical ways. Creative ways.

Junior PM: Even when the deck is stacked against them?

Senior PM: Especially then. That's when High Agency matters most.

Junior PM: Give me an example.

Senior PM: Remember when Slack couldn't get IT approval at companies?

Junior PM: Yeah?

Senior PM: They didn't whine about IT gatekeepers. They made a product that spread without IT.

Junior PM: That's a company. I'm one person.

Senior PM: Every high agency move starts with one person refusing to be blocked.

Junior PM: What if I try everything and still fail?

Senior PM: You'll fail forward. Low Agency people fail in place.

Junior PM: This is basically "extreme ownership" right?

Senior PM: It's beyond ownership. Ownership says "this is my responsibility."

Junior PM: And High Agency?

Senior PM: High Agency says "I'll find a way regardless."

Junior PM: So when engineering says they need 6 months...

Senior PM: You explore what would make it 3.

Junior PM: When design is bottlenecked...

Senior PM: You learn enough to unblock progress.

Junior PM: When sales wants features we shouldn't build...

Senior PM: You find what they really need and solve it differently.

Junior PM: This is just doing everyone's job.

Senior PM: No. It's refusing to let their constraints become your excuses.

Junior PM: How do I know if I'm being High Agency or just stubborn?

Senior PM: High Agency people change tactics constantly. Stubborn people bang their heads on the same wall.

Junior PM: So flexibility in method, rigidity in outcome?

Senior PM: Exactly.

Junior PM: What's the biggest High Agency move you've seen?

Senior PM: A PM whose product got killed. Instead of sulking, they analyzed why, found a adjacent problem, built a prototype on weekends, and got it funded.

Junior PM: That's insane effort.

Senior PM: That's High Agency.

Junior PM: I count at least five times this week I said "can't do anything about that."

Senior PM: Good. Awareness is step one.

Junior PM: What's step two?

Senior PM: Next time you think "can't," ask "what if I had to?"

Junior PM: Like if my job depended on it?

Senior PM: Like if someone you loved depended on it.

Junior PM: That changes the equation.

Senior PM: High Agency people live in that equation.

Junior PM: This sounds like a recipe for burnout.

Senior PM: Low Agency is the real burnout. Years of blaming "the system" while going nowhere.

Junior PM: At least High Agency burnout means you tried.

Senior PM: High Agency rarely burns out. It builds momentum.

Junior PM: Because you're actually making progress?

Senior PM: Because you're writing your story, not reading someone else's script.

Junior PM: Even in a big company with process and politics?

Senior PM: Especially there. That's where High Agency becomes a superpower.

note_tweet_text:
things no fullstack roadmap will ever teach you

(2/100) - JWT Basics 🔥

jwt (json web token) is the most abused auth tool in modern apps. everyone copies boilerplate, few actually understand it.  

what a jwt is:  
• a signed string (header.payload.signature)  
• base64 encoded, not encrypted  
• server signs it with a secret or private key  
• client stores it, sends with every request  

why people like it:  
• stateless - no db lookup on every request  
• works across web, mobile, api clients  
• easy to integrate with 3rd-party services  

where it goes wrong:  
• storing jwt in localStorage → vulnerable to xss  
• long-lived tokens → if stolen, attacker has access for months  
• putting sensitive data in payload → anyone can read it  
• no easy revocation → can’t just “log user out” instantly  

best practices:  
• keep access tokens short-lived (5–15 mins)  
• issue refresh tokens (httpOnly cookie) → rotate frequently  
• never put secrets or roles in the payload  
• use asymmetric signing (RS256) for higher-trust apps  
• validate audience, issuer, and expiry on every request  

fullstack angle:  
• frontend: handle token expiry → silent refresh before api calls  
• mobile: store refresh tokens securely (keychain/keystore)  
• backend: validate tokens with a middleware → reject tampered ones fast  
• infra: rotate signing keys, monitor for replay attempts  

👉🏻 mini-project idea:  
• next.js frontend → login with jwt auth  
• express backend → issues short access tokens + refresh tokens  
• redis store → blacklist/rotate refresh tokens  
• middleware → auto-reject expired/invalid tokens  
• frontend hook → refresh token logic before api calls  

this is how jwt goes from “tutorial toy” → production-ready auth.
